slides.title: Welcome to Modern Physics
slides.content:
# Introduction to Modern Physics ðŸš€

Welcome to **Modern Physics** - where classical physics breaks down and new rules emerge!

## What you'll learn:
- **Quantum Mechanics** - The physics of the very small
- **Nuclear Physics** - The heart of atoms
- **Special Relativity** - Space, time, and light
- **Semiconductors** - The foundation of electronics

> ðŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** Modern physics began around 1900 when classical physics couldn't explain blackbody radiation, leading to Planck's quantum hypothesis!

## Why "Modern" Physics?

Physics before ~1900: **Classical Physics**
- Newton's mechanics
- Maxwell's electromagnetism
- Thermodynamics

Physics after ~1900: **Modern Physics**
- Quantum mechanics
- Relativity
- Nuclear & particle physics

## Mind-Bending Concepts Ahead

| Classical View | Modern Reality |
|----------------|----------------|
| Continuous energy | Quantized in packets |
| Absolute time | Time is relative |
| Particles are particles | Wave-particle duality |
| Mass is constant | Mass increases with speed |

> âš ï¸ **Warning:** Your intuition from everyday life may fail here. That's okay - even Einstein was troubled by quantum mechanics!

Let's explore the strange and wonderful!

slides.title: The Photoelectric Effect
slides.content:
# The Photoelectric Effect ðŸ’¡

Light shining on metal can eject electrons - but not the way classical physics predicted!

## The Experiment

```
    Light (hf)
         â†“
    â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â• Metal surface
         â†“
    Electrons ejected (if f > fâ‚€)
```

## Classical Predictions (WRONG!)

- âŒ Brighter light should give electrons more energy
- âŒ Any frequency should work if bright enough
- âŒ Time delay expected for dim light

## Actual Observations

- âœ… Electron energy depends on light **frequency**, not intensity
- âœ… Below threshold frequency fâ‚€, NO electrons regardless of brightness
- âœ… Electrons emitted **instantly**, no delay
- âœ… Brighter light = more electrons, not faster ones

## Einstein's Explanation (1905)

Light comes in packets called **photons**!

```
E_photon = hf
```

| Symbol | Meaning | Value |
|--------|---------|-------|
| h | Planck's constant | 6.63 Ã— 10â»Â³â´ JÂ·s |
| f | Frequency | Hz |

## Photoelectric Equation

```
hf = Ï† + KE_max

KE_max = hf - Ï†
```

- Ï† (phi) = work function (minimum energy to escape)
- KE_max = maximum kinetic energy of ejected electron

## Work Functions

| Metal | Ï† (eV) |
|-------|--------|
| Cesium | 2.1 |
| Sodium | 2.3 |
| Zinc | 4.3 |
| Platinum | 5.6 |

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Einstein won his Nobel Prize for this, not relativity!

slides.title: Wave-Particle Duality
slides.content:
# Wave-Particle Duality ã€°ï¸

Light and matter exhibit BOTH wave AND particle properties!

## Evidence for Light as Waves

- Interference (Young's double slit)
- Diffraction
- Polarization

## Evidence for Light as Particles

- Photoelectric effect
- Compton scattering
- Blackbody radiation

## de Broglie's Hypothesis (1924)

> *"If light can be particles, maybe particles can be waves!"*

```
Î» = h/p = h/(mv)
```

| Symbol | Meaning |
|--------|--------|
| Î» | de Broglie wavelength |
| h | Planck's constant |
| p | Momentum |
| m | Mass |
| v | Velocity |

## de Broglie Wavelengths

| Object | Wavelength |
|--------|------------|
| Electron (slow) | ~1 nm |
| Electron (fast) | ~0.01 nm |
| Baseball | ~10â»Â³â´ m (unmeasurable!) |
| Human | ~10â»Â³âµ m |

## Electron Diffraction

Electrons passing through crystals create diffraction patterns - proving their wave nature!

## The Complementarity Principle

> *We can observe wave OR particle behavior, never both simultaneously.*

- When we detect "which path": Particle behavior
- When we don't detect path: Wave behavior (interference)

> ðŸ’¡ **Deep Insight:** The observer's choice of experiment determines what we see!

# The Bohr Model ðŸ”µ

Niels Bohr (1913) combined quantum ideas with atomic structure.

## Bohr's Postulates

### 1. Quantized Orbits
Electrons can only exist in specific orbits with fixed energies.

### 2. Stationary States
Electrons don't radiate energy while in an allowed orbit.

### 3. Quantum Jumps
Electrons emit/absorb photons when jumping between orbits.

```
        n=3  â”â”â”â”â”â”â”  Eâ‚ƒ
                â†“ photon (Eâ‚ƒ-Eâ‚‚)
        n=2  â”â”â”â”â”â”â”  Eâ‚‚
                â†“ photon (Eâ‚‚-Eâ‚)
        n=1  â”â”â”â”â”â”â”  Eâ‚ (ground state)
```

## Energy Levels of Hydrogen

```
Eâ‚™ = -13.6 eV / nÂ²
```

| n | Energy (eV) | Name |
|---|-------------|------|
| 1 | -13.6 | Ground state |
| 2 | -3.4 | First excited |
| 3 | -1.51 | Second excited |
| âˆž | 0 | Ionized |

## Photon Emission

```
hf = Eáµ¢ - Eá¶ 
```

The frequency of emitted light matches the energy difference!

## Spectral Series

| Series | Transitions to n= | Wavelength |
|--------|-------------------|------------|
| Lyman | 1 | UV |
| Balmer | 2 | Visible |
| Paschen | 3 | Infrared |

## Limitations

- Works perfectly for hydrogen
- Fails for multi-electron atoms
- Replaced by quantum mechanics

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Energy quantization explains why atoms emit specific colors!

# Nuclear Fission ðŸ’¥

Fission is the **splitting of a heavy nucleus** into lighter fragments, releasing tremendous energy.

## The Fission Process

```
    n + Â²Â³âµU â†’ Â²Â³â¶U* â†’ Â¹â´â´Ba + â¸â¹Kr + 3n + Energy
      (unstable)              (new neutrons!)
```

## Energy Released

~200 MeV per fission event!

Compare: Chemical burning releases ~10 eV per reaction.

Fission releases ~20 million times more energy!

## Chain Reaction

```

      (1)   (3)     (9)     (27)...
```

## Critical Mass

Minimum amount of fissile material needed to sustain chain reaction.

| Material | Critical Mass |
|----------|---------------|
| Â²Â³âµU (bare sphere) | ~52 kg |
| Â²Â³â¹Pu (bare sphere) | ~10 kg |

## Controlling Fission

slides.title: Nuclear Fusion
slides.content:
# Nuclear Fusion â˜€ï¸

Fusion is the **combining of light nuclei** into heavier ones, releasing even more energy than fission!

## The Fusion Process

```
Â²H + Â³H â†’ â´He + n + 17.6 MeV
(deuterium + tritium â†’ helium + neutron + energy)
```

## Why Fusion is Hard

Nuclei are positive â†’ They repel!

Need extreme conditions:
- Temperature: ~100 million Â°C
- Pressure: Enormous confinement

## Fusion in Stars

### Proton-Proton Chain (Sun)
```
4Â¹H â†’ â´He + 2eâº + 2Î½ + 26.7 MeV
```

The Sun converts 600 million tons of hydrogen to helium every second!

## Fusion vs Fission

| Property | Fission | Fusion |
|----------|---------|--------|
| Process | Split heavy | Combine light |
| Fuel | Uranium, Plutonium | Hydrogen isotopes |
| Energy/reaction | ~200 MeV | ~17 MeV |
| Energy/kg fuel | ~80 TJ | ~340 TJ |
| Waste | Long-lived | Short-lived |

| **Tokamak** | Magnetic confinement |

- International fusion reactor

slides.title: Special Relativity: Postulates
slides.content:
# Special Relativity â±ï¸

Albert Einstein's 1905 theory revolutionized our understanding of space and time.

## The Two Postulates

### 1. Principle of Relativity
> *The laws of physics are the same in all inertial reference frames.*

No experiment can distinguish between uniform motion and rest.

### 2. Constancy of Light Speed
> *The speed of light in vacuum is the same for all observers, regardless of their motion.*

c = 3 Ã— 10â¸ m/s - always!

## Why This is Strange

**Normal objects:**
If you throw a ball at 10 m/s from a car moving at 20 m/s:
- Observer on ground sees 30 m/s

**Light:**
If you shine light from a car moving at any speed:
- Everyone measures c, not c + v!

## Consequences

| Effect | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| Time dilation | Moving clocks run slower |
| Length contraction | Moving objects are shorter |
| Mass increase | Objects get heavier at high speeds |
| Simultaneity | What's simultaneous depends on observer |

## What "Special" Means

- **Special** Relativity: Constant velocity (inertial frames)
- **General** Relativity: Includes acceleration and gravity

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Insight:** Space and time are not absolute - they're relative to the observer!

slides.title: Time Dilation and Length Contraction
slides.content:
# Time Dilation & Length Contraction ðŸ“

## Time Dilation

Moving clocks tick **slower**!

```
Î”t = Î³Î”tâ‚€

Î³ = 1/âˆš(1 - vÂ²/cÂ²)  (Lorentz factor)
```

| Speed (v) | Î³ | Time dilation |
|-----------|---|---------------|
| 0 | 1.00 | None |
| 0.5c | 1.15 | 15% slower |
| 0.9c | 2.29 | 2.3Ã— slower |
| 0.99c | 7.09 | 7Ã— slower |
| 0.999c | 22.4 | 22Ã— slower |

## The Twin Paradox

One twin travels at high speed, the other stays home.

Traveling twin returns **younger** than stay-at-home twin!

(Actually observed with cosmic ray muons and atomic clocks on planes!)

## Length Contraction

Moving objects are **shorter** in direction of motion!

```
L = Lâ‚€/Î³ = Lâ‚€âˆš(1 - vÂ²/cÂ²)
```

| Speed | Length |
|-------|--------|
| 0.5c | 87% of rest length |
| 0.9c | 44% of rest length |
| 0.99c | 14% of rest length |

## What Contracts?

- Only the dimension parallel to motion
- Perpendicular dimensions unaffected
- The object doesn't "feel" squeezed

## Real-World Evidence

### Muon Lifetime
- Muons live ~2.2 Î¼s in lab
- Should travel ~660 m
- Actually reach Earth's surface (~10 km)!
- Time dilation extends their lifetime

> ðŸ’¡ **Mind-bender:** From muon's perspective, the atmosphere is length-contracted!

slides.content:
# E = mcÂ² âš¡

The most famous equation in physics!

## What It Means

Mass and energy are **interchangeable**:

```
E = mcÂ²
```

| Symbol | Meaning |
|--------|--------|
| E | Energy (J) |
| m | Mass (kg) |
| cÂ² | (3Ã—10â¸)Â² = 9Ã—10Â¹â¶ mÂ²/sÂ² |

## Implications

- A small mass = enormous energy
- 1 kg of matter = 9 Ã— 10Â¹â¶ J
- That's ~25 billion kWh!

## Relativistic Mass & Energy

### Total Energy
```
E = Î³mcÂ² = mcÂ²/âˆš(1 - vÂ²/cÂ²)
```

### Rest Energy
```
Eâ‚€ = mcÂ² (when v = 0)
```

### Kinetic Energy (Relativistic)
```
KE = (Î³ - 1)mcÂ²
```

## Applications of E = mcÂ²

| Application | How |
|-------------|-----|
| Nuclear power | Mass converted to energy |
| PET scans | Positron annihilation |
| Particle accelerators | Energy â†’ mass (new particles) |
| Sun's energy | Hydrogen â†’ Helium + energy |

## Mass Deficit Example

**Helium-4 nucleus:**
- 2 protons + 2 neutrons = 4.0330 u
- Actual He-4 mass = 4.0026 u
- "Missing" mass = 0.0304 u
- Became 28.3 MeV of binding energy!

## Why You Can't Reach c

As v â†’ c, Î³ â†’ âˆž

Requires infinite energy to accelerate mass to light speed!

> ðŸŽ¯ **Profound Truth:** Mass is just a very concentrated form of energy!
